title: Emmy Krüger
text:
Emmy Krüger (27 November 1886 – 13 March 1976) was a German <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="soprano">soprano</a>.
Krüger was born in <a href="Frankfurt%20am%20Main">Frankfurt am Main</a>. She notably portrayed the title role in the world première of <a href="Erich%20Wolfgang%20Korngold">Erich Wolfgang Korngold</a>'s "<a href="Violanta">Violanta</a>" at the <a href="National%20Theatre%20Munich">National Theatre Munich</a> in 1916. In 1917, she created the role of Silla in the première of <a href="Hans%20Pfitzner">Hans Pfitzner</a>'s "<a href="Palestrina%20%28opera%29">Palestrina</a>" at the <a href="Prinzregententheater">Prinzregententheater</a>. Occasionally she sang <a href="mezzo-soprano">mezzo-soprano</a> parts such as Octavian in <a href="Richard%20Strauss">Richard Strauss</a>'s "<a href="Der%20Rosenkavalier">Der Rosenkavalier</a>", which she has sung as early as 1911 in <a href="Z%C3%BCrich">Zürich</a> and again in 1918 under the composer's baton. She was a regular performer at the <a href="Bayreuth%20Festival">Bayreuth Festival</a> during the 1920s and 1930s where her most frequently assailed role was that of Isolde in <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>'s "<a href="Tristan%20und%20Isolde">Tristan und Isolde</a>". She had a long-time romantic relationship with Swiss millionaire's wife, Olympic equestrian sportswoman and amateur photographer <a href="Ren%C3%A9e%20Schwarzenbach-Wille">Renée Schwarzenbach-Wille</a>, who was the mother of writer <a href="Annemarie%20Schwarzenbach">Annemarie Schwarzenbach</a>. She died, aged 89, in <a href="Zurich">Zurich</a>.
